Use the Phonics/Syllable Cards or write the prefixes un-, re-, and dis-. Read each one and have students repeat.
Explain that a prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word. It changes the words meaning.
Add the prefix un- to clear (unclear), re- to name (rename), and dis- to agree (disagree). Model for students how to read the new word formed.
Explain that un- and dis- can mean not or the opposite of. Re- means again. Unclear means not clear. Rename means name again. Disagree means the opposite of agree.

Continue by adding prefixes to these words: (dis) grace, (re) wash, (un) lucky, (re) join, (dis) color, (un) sealed. Guide students to read the words and determine the new words meaning. Point out that the prefix is a separate syllable.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
This is the /a/ square. Add a square to show me at.
Students should add a different color square after the purple /a/ square. Say:
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /a/ square.

Explain that Oct. is an abbreviation of October. Read aloud the abbreviation Oct. as October and have students repeat.

Tell students that an abbreviation is a shortened version of a word that frequently ends with a period. Titles, months, and days are often abbreviated, or shortened, in writing. Abbreviations for proper nouns are capitalized.

Point out that the abbreviation Oct. includes the first few letters of the word, followed by a period. Explain that some other abbreviations have different patterns, such as Dr. for Doctor. Tell students they will have to remember these abbreviations.
Continue by writing the abbreviations for these words: Missus (Mrs.), April (Apr.), Road (Rd.), Monday (Mon.), Avenue (Ave.). Have students read them aloud.

Explain that Oct. is an abbreviation of October. Read aloud the abbreviation Oct. as October and have students repeat.

Tell students that an abbreviation is a shortened version of a word that frequently ends with a period. Titles, months, and days are often abbreviated, or shortened, in writing. Abbreviations for proper nouns are capitalized.

Point out that the abbreviation Oct. includes the first few letters of the word, followed by a period. Explain that some other abbreviations have different patterns, such as Dr. for Doctor. Tell students they will have to remember these abbreviations.
Continue by writing the abbreviations for these words: Missus (Mrs.), April (Apr.), Road (Rd.), Monday (Mon.), Avenue (Ave.). Have students read them aloud.
